comments:
On a development driver of RAD (March 15), which is based on org.eclipse.jst.jsp.core_1.0.100.v200602050611.jar

When I edit a JSP file, or when I open/close a web deployment editor, the DTD for the LTD XML file is retrieved from java.sun.com each time, even when the DTD is mentioned in the XML catalog in Window>Preferences.

I see the following stackdumps appearing:

Once per JSP editor:

On a spotty connection, this slows down any processing that involved tld files.

Thanks Chris. 

This might be sort of a dup of bug 125829 but ... that bug does not mention this XML Catalog issue ... which is important to settle. 

Lawrence ... as you have 'cache', have you also absorbed catalog? 

Have we yet developed the junit tests or infrastructure to test we never access internet, if not expected?
For reference: http://xerces.apache.org/xerces2-j/faq-xcatalogs.html

From the stack it looks like
org.eclipse.jst.jsp.core.internal.util.DocumentProvider._getParsedDocumentDOM2(DocumentProvider.java:95)
is not using the URI resolver but calling out to the internet directly. Nitin, can you confirm that the JSP editor makes use of the URI resolution framework?

David - I don't believe there are JUnit tests that test WTP as a whole to determine that no internet access is occurring. These tests will likely need to be tool specific as any tool can simply call out to the internet on its own.

Created an attachment (id=37090)
A potential patch that makes use of the URI resolution framework

This patch updates the method shown above to make use of the URI resolution framework. I haven't confirmed that this completely solves the problem (as I'm not really sure what I need in my JSP to reproduce) and am not 100% confident I haven't broken anything. 

Nitin - I'd appreciate a review and your feedback.

I tried the patch and see no changes in behavior.

To replicate this problem, try this: Launch in debug mode and set a breakpoint in Socket.getInputStream.

Bearing in mind that "RAD" is using an old snapshot of the JSP Core plugin (bad "RAD"!), the problem should already be addressed in more recent I-builds.  On 2/9 the DocumentProvider class was altered so that external entities would return a zero-length input stream to the DOM parser, fixing bug 125829.  That class is used only to parse .tld files and thus no validation of the incoming XML is required.

In a sense, the catalog *shouldn't* be involved, nor should any function outside of the jsp.core plugin as this runs in a critical path while building JSP models.  For that reason, among others, the JSP editor does *not* use the common URI resolver framework to locate referenced tag libraries and included JSP fragments.

I must admit I lost the train of thought here.

All my experiments have been on Eclipse 3.2 M5 + WTP M5. I see socket connections, and I see an XML catalog. When I google on both, the answer is to locally cache DTDs.
Sorry, I mean my experiments starting at comment #6

Chris, one question about comment #6, the first run will still require an internet connection to download and cache whatever remote resource you're accessing. (A DTD in this case.) Did you still see the internet activity on subsequent runs?
I disagree. We have local cache for that as specified in the XML Catalog. WTP should work completely disconnected from the network.

My apologies. You're correct. If you specify the entry in the XML catalog there is no reason for a network connection to occur. Only in the case that the entry is not available locally should a network request occur.

(In reply to comment #6)
> I see the following connections still being made when I do a clean workspace
> with a couple of JSP files (I imported org.eclipse.help.webapp):

org.eclipse.help.webapp includes a web.xml that would probably make a validator connect to java.sun.com for its DTD, but I can't think of a reason for it to connect to the mentioned IBM sites.

If it's requesting the J2EE 1.4 schema, that schema contains an import statement for a schema residing on an IBM server.

See http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee/j2ee_1_4.xsd
Lawrence, at least straight from CVS, it's just referencing the DTD http://java.sun.com/j2ee/dtds/web-app_2.2.dtd.  Should I reopen and assign to you so you can track down the remainder?

Sure. I'm still not sure exactly where the problem is or how to reproduce. The original comment states "When I edit a JSP file, or when I open/close a web deployment editor." 

Is the problem when validating the deployment descriptor (web.xml) or a JSP? Can you provide specific instructions to reproduce the problem with a clean workspace?
With the "editing a JSP" part of it out of the picture on more recent code, I'd focus on the deployment descriptor and interactions with the cache and catalog.

Instructions:

- install WTP M5
- set a breakpoint in Socket.getInputStream to detect socket activity
- launch in debug mode with a new workspace
- in runtime workbench, import org.eclipse.help.webapp
- on that project, run validation (red crosses appear slowly in the explorer)

- A build will start automatically

Again, all on WTP 1.5. No RAD instances were harmed in this exercise.

I just tried to reproduce the problem again with a clean install of WTP 1.5M5 and am still seeing the behaviour I expect. WTP does not come preconfigured with any J2EE schemas or DTDs in the XML catalog. When running scenario 1 in a clean workspace I see that Socket.getInputStream is called to retrieve the license and the DTD. The DTD is then cached (if the license is accepted) and no further calls are made on subsequent validations. I also tried adding the DTD to the XML catalog. I created an entry for the following:
PublicID = "-//Sun Microsystems, Inc.//DTD Web Application 2.2//EN"
URI = "platform:/resource/test/web-app_2_2.dtd"
This entry prevented any calls to Socket.getInputStream.

For scenario 2 I created a new Enterprise Application using the toolbar. This created a new project in my workspace and Socket.getInputStream was called to retreive all of the J2EE schemas required to validate the deployment descriptor. Subsequent validation calls did not result in any calls to Socket.getInputStream. I also tried adding the required schemas to the XML catalog. Adding the following three entries to the XML catalog prevented any calls to Socket.getInputStream:
Schema Location = "http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee/application_1_4.xsd"
uri = "platform:/resource/test/application_1_4.xsd"
Schema Location = "http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee/j2ee_1_4.xsd"
uri = "platform:/resource/test/j2ee_1_4.xsd"
Schema Location = "http://www.ibm.com/webservices/xsd/j2ee_web_services_client_1_1.xsd"
uri = "platform:/resource/test/j2ee_web_services_client_1_1.xsd"
As far as I've seen there is not deployment editor in WTP. The deployment descriptor is simply manipulated using the XML editor. Using this editor did not result in any calls to Socket.getInputStream after validation had been run.

As far as I can tell this is working as expected. Can you provide any more details about reproducing the problem? How is your XML catalog configured? Are you seeing network access on subsequent validation runs on just the first validation run?

I noticed the dialog with the cache request from developers.sun.com. However, I could not accept the license agreement. I work for a company where I have to ask permission to download software that has a license agreement.

You are right. After the second run of all the scenarios, no longer is a socket connection opened. However, my XML catalog shows 15 plugin specified entries in my empty workspace. Can't we add the other ones that are often used (the ones needed by an empty EAR project, for instance). 

Pre-caching more DTDs in a jar would definitely improve the initial out-of-the-box experience for WTP.

When starting a new workspace while being disconnected (like on an airplane), it takes 35 seconds to create an empty enterprise application, and 30 seconds to build it. There is no feedback or explanation what the wait is for.
From home, over VPN, on a cable modem, I found socket connections are erratic, generating random long delays also. Then the timeouts are per socket, and not for the entire session. 

Suggestion: add more cached DTDs to the current XML catalog

Chris, I appreciate the suggestion and definitely agree with you. There have been several bugs opened requesting the DTDs and schemas be included in WTP including bug 82261 and bug 84926. While we're still pursuing legal approval to include the Sun licensed J2EE schemas and DTDs in WTP we do not currently have permission to bundle them.

That said, there should not be a delay when validating disconnected without the schemas and DTDs. Bug 112970 is open to track this request.

I'm going to resolve this bug as works for me. Feel free to reopen if you disagree or don't feel that one of the other bugs I've listed adequately covers your concerns.
This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP bugs which are in the resolved state without an appropriate targeted version.  If you feel this bug was closed inappropriately, please reopen.
